text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of black and red text with a framed quatrefoil image inserted between lines; wide margins with vine-scroll decoration; clear visual hierarchy placing the image centrally between text blocks

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata in brown ink with red rubrication; professional book hand with regular ruling and decorative flourishes

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for background diaper pattern and royal fleur-de-lis to signify sovereignty; deep blue mantle denotes royal status; red used for king’s book and textual rubrics; green and white highlights accentuate figures; layered application with white lead highlight and burnished gesso under gold; alternating color patterns in background motif; pigments remain well-preserved with minimal darkening

features: centralized royal figure flanked by clerical group on left and secular attendants on right
figures arranged within a quatrefoil medallion frame
vertical axis emphasized by king’s crown and staff
balanced color distribution between left and right groups

decorative_elements: quatrefoil frame with alternating white and red border
diapered honeycomb background with gold roundels
gold fleur-de-lis pattern on royal robe

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outline in dark brown ink with varying line weights for drapery and facial features
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatching; white lead highlights on folds and faces; burnished gesso under gold for relief
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling (king larger than attendants); shallow space achieved by overlapping without linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: A single coronation-like scene: the central figure, a crowned king seated on a cushioned throne, wears a dark blue robe patterned with gold fleur-de-lis. He holds a long staff topped with a cross. To his left two bishops in mitres and chasubles lean forward, one placing a hand on the staff, the other holding his crosier. Their vestments are rendered in draped folds of greyish white with gilt accents. Behind them kneels a clerical attendant. To the king’s right stand four secular men in grey tunics and simple hats; one gestures toward the king with an outstretched finger, another leans in, as if offering counsel. All figures occupy a shallow spatial plane against a richly patterned diaper background of alternating black and gold roundels. The quatrefoil frame confines the group, focusing attention on the hierarchical scale of the monarch. The balanced arrangement, overlapping forms, and gestures establish interactions: clerical sanction of royal power on the left and secular acknowledgement on the right.

religious: Two bishops wearing mitres and chasubles holding crosiers
secular: King wearing fleur-de-lis patterned blue robe and golden crown seated on cushioned throne
Four secular attendants in grey tunics and hats gesturing toward the king

natural: Vine scroll with stylized foliate leaves

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, extremely smooth surface with faint hair-follicle pattern; ruled for text columns; quarto gatherings
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight red pigment flaking in vermilion areas; stable gold leaf with no major losses; minor cockling at lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in background pattern
Regular plummet ruling across entire page
Visible brush strokes in drapery layers
Punchwork diaper pattern in gold leaf

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This mid-14th-century Anglo-Norman manuscript illumination was likely produced in a Parisian workshop for a noble patron seeking both instruction in royal genealogy and a demonstration of wealth. The use of burnished gold leaf for the fleur-de-lis pattern and the diapered background aligns with French courtly illumination traditions under Philip VI, emphasizing dynastic legitimacy. The Gothic textura quadrata script and high-quality vellum indicate a luxury commission. Stylistically, the symmetrical composition and quatrefoil frame reflect innovations of the Paris School in flattening space to focus on hierarchical relationships. Multiple hands appear evident: a master hand in the central royal figure and a specialist in marginal vine scroll ornament. The iconography—bishop placing staff on the king, flanked by secular witnesses—visually asserts the sacred sanction of monarchy, echoing contemporary political theology that fused ecclesiastical and secular power. Comparatively, this image shares compositional parallels with the Grandes Chroniques de France, yet its quatrefoil containment and patterned background recall earlier English Channel School experiments. The illumination thus bridges traditional typologies of throne-room imagery with novel spatial compression, illustrating both continuity and innovation within 14th-century French book production.
